user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_disk_version:
```c
static uint32_t lfs_fs_disk_version(lfs_t *lfs) {
    (void)lfs;
#ifdef LFS_MULTIVERSION
    if (lfs->cfg->disk_version) {
        return lfs->cfg->disk_version;
    } else
#endif
    {
        return LFS_DISK_VERSION;
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
#ifdef LFS_MULTIVERSION
    if (lfs->cfg->disk_version) {
        return lfs->cfg->disk_version;
    } else
#endif
    {
        return LFS_DISK_VERSION;
    }
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: When LFS_MULTIVERSION is defined the controlling expression is 'lfs->cfg->disk_version', which is a runtime value derived from the function parameter and configuration structure and thus not an invariant. When LFS_MULTIVERSION is not defined there is no controlling statement at all (the code reduces to returning LFS_DISK_VERSION). Therefore no controlling expression is an invariant and Rule 14.3 is not violated.
